  + All your text, code and output in one place<br><br>
  + Generate reproducible, high quality reports that can be shared in may ways<br><br>

# Anatomy of a code chunk

````markdown
`r ''````{r chunk-label, results='hide', fig.height=4}


`r ""````
````

.big[A code chunk can be added by Ctrl + Alt + i or Cmd + options + i]

  .big[The include option can be set to TRUE or FALSE]. 
  
  _Setting it to true will hide the code as well as the results._

# The `eval` option

  .big[The eval option can be set to TRUE or FALSE]. 
  
  _Setting it to false means that this particular chunk will not be executed_
  
  This is usually used to display code, like in much of my slides.

class: left

# Step 4 - Handling figure outputs

Using the chunk options we can control for:

  + Alignment of the figure. .big[`fig.align = 'center'`]
  + Size of the figure. .big[`out.width = '25%'`]
  + Caption for the figure. .big[`fig.cap = 'about your chart'`]
  
Copy this code and play with figure chunk options, Knit your document

```{r eval=FALSE}

penguins %>% 
  ggplot(aes(bill_length_mm,bill_depth_mm))+
  geom_jitter(aes(colour = species),alpha = 0.8)+
  scale_colour_manual(values = c("#2bc846","#4ec2f3","#ffc740"))+
  labs(
    x= "Bill depth (mm)",
    y= "Bill length (mm)"
  )+
  theme_minimal()

```

# Parameterised Reporting

.big[User specified customized reporting]

Example:
  + Results related to specific location
  + Results for desired groups
  + Same analysis with different assumptions

class: middle

# Declaring Params

```
title: My Document
output: html_document
params:
  year: 2018
  region: Europe
  printcode: TRUE
  data: file.csv
```

# Knitting with Parameters

There are three ways in which a parameterized report can be knitted:

  + Using the Knit button within RStudio.
  
  + rmarkdown::render() with the params argument.
  
  + Using an interactive user interface to input parameter values.
  
.small[Text from R4DS]

# Knit Using `rmarkdown::render()`

```{r eval=FALSE}
rmarkdown::render(input = "YOur-markdown.rmd",
                  params = list(
                    type = "Unsolved",
                    region = "west"
                  )
                  )
```
